articles.headline: Trapped in a Pandemic Funk: Millions of Americans Can’t Shake a Gloomy Outlook
articles.snippet: Despite signals that the economy is improving and the virus is waning, many Americans said they were frustrated by polarized politics and a sense of stagnancy.
articles.abstract: Despite signals that the economy is improving and the virus is waning, many Americans said they were frustrated by polarized politics and a sense of stagnancy.
articles.lead_paragraph: A year ago, Michael Macey, a barber who lives in the suburbs outside Atlanta, was thrilled to help propel President Biden to victory, hopeful that Democrats would move swiftly to tackle policing laws and other big issues. But then he watched his hopes for sweeping changes wither in Washington.
articles.byline: By Jack Healy, Audra D. S. Burch and Patricia Mazzei

articles.headline: House Passes $1 Trillion Infrastructure Bill, Putting Social Policy Bill on Hold
articles.snippet: Progressives who had threatened to sink the measure agreed to support it after extracting a promise from moderates that they would ultimately back the social safety net and climate bill.
articles.abstract: Progressives who had threatened to sink the measure agreed to support it after extracting a promise from moderates that they would ultimately back the social safety net and climate bill.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Follow our live coverage of President Biden signing the infrastructure bill.]
articles.byline: By Jonathan Weisman, Emily Cochrane and Catie Edmondson

articles.headline: Can Progress on Diversity Be Union-Made?
articles.snippet: In Boston, setting a goal for a racially diverse construction work force is one thing. Meeting it has proved more difficult.
articles.abstract: In Boston, setting a goal for a racially diverse construction work force is one thing. Meeting it has proved more difficult.
articles.lead_paragraph: Staring at the wall of glass clawing its way up the unfinished facade of the Winthrop Center in downtown Boston — 53 floors of commercial and residential space soaring 690 feet — Travis Watson isn’t interested in the grandeur of the thing. He wants to know who’s working on it.
articles.byline: By Eduardo Porter and Tony Luong

articles.headline: How Police Justify Killing Drivers: The Vehicle Was a Weapon
articles.snippet: A Times investigation into a common defense for shooting motorists found that some officers had put themselves in danger. Others appeared to face no peril at all.
articles.abstract: A Times investigation into a common defense for shooting motorists found that some officers had put themselves in danger. Others appeared to face no peril at all.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHENIX CITY, Ala. — On a Sunday in May 2017, a patrol car sat outside the city’s oldest public housing project, waiting for anyone acting suspiciously. The two police officers heard Cedric Mifflin before they saw him, blasting music from a silver Mercury Grand Marquis. Then they tried to pull him over: He wasn’t wearing a seatbelt.
articles.byline: By Kim Barker, Steve Eder, David D. Kirkpatrick and Arya Sundaram

articles.headline: A Turtle, a Pool and the Fight to Save Puerto Rico’s Beaches
articles.snippet: An attempt to rebuild a beachfront pool turned into a much bigger story about the threats of erosion and overdevelopment on the island.
articles.abstract: An attempt to rebuild a beachfront pool turned into a much bigger story about the threats of erosion and overdevelopment on the island.
articles.lead_paragraph: RINCÓN, P.R. — The turtle, presumably, had no way of knowing it would become a symbol of protest when it got stuck for hours in a construction site on a beach in western Puerto Rico, unable to return to the sea.
articles.byline: By Patricia Mazzei and Erika P. Rodriguez

articles.headline: How a $1 Trillion Infrastructure Bill Survived an Intraparty Brawl
articles.snippet: Speaker Nancy Pelosi agreed to a deal proposed by the Congressional Black Caucus, mobilizing one faction of Democratic lawmakers to win over two others.
articles.abstract: Speaker Nancy Pelosi agreed to a deal proposed by the Congressional Black Caucus, mobilizing one faction of Democratic lawmakers to win over two others.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Follow our live coverage of President Biden signing the infrastructure bill.]
articles.byline: By Jonathan Weisman and Carl Hulse

articles.headline: Democrats Thought They Bottomed Out in Rural, White America. It Wasn’t the Bottom.
articles.snippet: Republicans ran up the margins in rural Virginia counties, the latest sign that Democrats, as one lawmaker put it, “continue to tank in small-town America.”
articles.abstract: Republicans ran up the margins in rural Virginia counties, the latest sign that Democrats, as one lawmaker put it, “continue to tank in small-town America.”
articles.lead_paragraph: HOT SPRINGS, Va. — The increasingly liberal politics of Virginia had been a sore spot for residents of this conservative town of 499 people nestled in the Allegheny Mountains. But this past week, as Republicans stormed to marquee victories powered in part by turnout in rural areas like Bath County, local voters cheered.
articles.byline: By Astead W. Herndon and Shane Goldmacher

articles.headline: ‘No Way Out’: A Sudden Life-and-Death Struggle at a Houston Concert
articles.snippet: Eight people died at Travis Scott’s Astroworld festival, and hundreds more were injured as investigators sought to determine why and how a surging crowd turned deadly.
articles.abstract: Eight people died at Travis Scott’s Astroworld festival, and hundreds more were injured as investigators sought to determine why and how a surging crowd turned deadly.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Panic and then desperation spread through the crowd of 50,000 mostly young people just as the popular hometown rapper they had come to see, Travis Scott, took the stage Friday night. It came like a wave, an unstoppable movement of bodies that could not be held back.
articles.byline: By J. David Goodman and Maria Jimenez Moya

articles.headline: To Steer China’s Future, Xi Is Rewriting Its Past
articles.snippet: A new official summation of Communist Party history is likely to exalt Xi Jinping as a peer of Mao and Deng, fortifying his claim to a new phase in power.
articles.abstract: A new official summation of Communist Party history is likely to exalt Xi Jinping as a peer of Mao and Deng, fortifying his claim to a new phase in power.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Follow live updates on the meeting between President Biden and China’s leader, Xi Jinping.]

articles.headline: Witnesses to the End
articles.snippet: The young Marines in Kabul were left to determine who was evacuated from Afghanistan and who was left behind. The cost was high.
articles.abstract: The young Marines in Kabul were left to determine who was evacuated from Afghanistan and who was left behind. The cost was high.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Marines at Abbey Gate were racing against time. The crowd at the gate didn’t know it, but the Marines had been told to close it at 6 p.m.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Why the Media Loves Labor Now
articles.snippet: At a moment of political turmoil, economic change and a pandemic-driven focus on how we work, labor has become a hot news beat.
articles.abstract: At a moment of political turmoil, economic change and a pandemic-driven focus on how we work, labor has become a hot news beat.
articles.lead_paragraph: The top story in the weekly print edition of The Chief-Leader, a publication that has long covered New York City’s civil servants, is often about the hottest job listing in town. Last week, it was, “Bus Operator Jobs With MTA Starting at $23.84 an Hour.”

articles.headline: Houston Officials Worried About Crowd Control Before Travis Scott Took the Stage
articles.snippet: On the day of the show, the Houston police chief said that he visited Mr. Scott in his trailer and shared his concerns about the crowd.
articles.abstract: On the day of the show, the Houston police chief said that he visited Mr. Scott in his trailer and shared his concerns about the crowd.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Concert organizers and Houston city officials knew that the crowd at a music festival planned by Travis Scott, a favorite local rapper turned megastar, could be difficult to control. That’s what happened two years earlier, the last time Mr. Scott held his Astroworld Festival.
articles.byline: By J. David Goodman and Edgar Sandoval

articles.headline: Retailers Scramble to Attract Workers Ahead of the Holidays
articles.snippet: Signing bonuses, higher wages, even college tuition. Companies are using perks to entice new employees in an industry that has been battered by the pandemic.
articles.abstract: Signing bonuses, higher wages, even college tuition. Companies are using perks to entice new employees in an industry that has been battered by the pandemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: Macy’s is offering referral bonuses of up to $500 for each friend or family member that employees recruit to join the company. Walmart is paying as much as $17 an hour to start and has begun offering free college tuition to its workers. And some Amazon warehouse jobs now command signing bonuses of up to $3,000.
articles.byline: By Sapna Maheshwari and Michael Corkery

articles.headline: Chip Shortage Creates New Power Players
articles.snippet: Low-profile chip makers with aging factories have become surprisingly powerful, leading to industry changes that may outlive the pandemic-fueled supply crunch.
articles.abstract: Low-profile chip makers with aging factories have become surprisingly powerful, leading to industry changes that may outlive the pandemic-fueled supply crunch.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Since 1989, Microchip Technology has operated in an unglamorous backwater of the electronics industry, making chips called microcontrollers that add computing power to cars, industrial equipment and many other products.

articles.headline: In Romania, Hard-Hit by Covid, Doctors Fight Vaccine Refusal
articles.snippet: An anti-vaccine clarion call by leading religious figures, echoed by prominent politicians and social media, helps explain why Romania now has the world’s highest Covid death rate.
articles.abstract: An anti-vaccine clarion call by leading religious figures, echoed by prominent politicians and social media, helps explain why Romania now has the world’s highest Covid death rate.
articles.lead_paragraph: COPACENI, Romania — As a new wave of the coronavirus pandemic crashed over Eastern Europe last month, devastating unvaccinated populations, an Orthodox Church bishop in southern Romania offered solace to his flock: “Don’t be fooled by what you see on TV — don’t be scared of Covid.”

articles.headline: Winter Heating Bills Loom as the Next Inflation Threat
articles.snippet: After plunging during the pandemic as the economy slowed, energy prices have roared upward. Washington is already moving to offer homeowners relief.
articles.abstract: After plunging during the pandemic as the economy slowed, energy prices have roared upward. Washington is already moving to offer homeowners relief.
articles.lead_paragraph: With consumers already dealing with the fastest price increases in decades, another unwelcome uptick is on the horizon: a widely expected increase in winter heating bills.

articles.headline: Randal Quarles, formerly the Fed’s vice chair for supervision, will leave the central bank at the end of December.
articles.snippet: Mr. Quarles’s term as a governor could have stretched until 2032. His departure will give the Biden administration more room to remake the Fed.
articles.abstract: Mr. Quarles’s term as a governor could have stretched until 2032. His departure will give the Biden administration more room to remake the Fed.
articles.lead_paragraph: Randal K. Quarles, a Federal Reserve governor who spent four years overseeing bank supervision, will step down from the Fed in December — opening an additional seat that will allow the Biden administration to reshape the central bank’s leadership.
